docs.summary: An upload button enables site visitors to upload files to your site.
description: ### Typical File Upload Scenario
In a typical scenario, the page from which files are uploaded contains
an upload button and another element, such as a regular button.
1. The site visitor chooses which file to upload by clicking the upload button and selecting the file in a native file chooser dialog.
1. At that point the file is stored in the upload button's `value` property as a `File` object.
1. The `onChange()` event is fired.

1. Validations on the file are performed, following which the `valid`, `validity`, and `validationMessage` properties are updated. Because `onChange()` is fired before validations are performed, do not check any of the validation properties in the code of the `onChange()` event handler. For example, do not code an if statement that checks the `valid` property in the `onChange()` because the property at this point contains values prior to the `onChange()`.
1. The site visitor triggers an event, such as a button click, on the other element.
1. That element's event handler calls the `startUpload()` function to perform the actual upload.
1. The upload either succeeds and returns an `UploadedFile` object, or fails and returns an `UploadError` object.
### Example
This example uploads a file when the site visitor clicks on a button. First it sets
the type of the file a site visitor can choose. Then the example
checks to see if the site visitor has chosen a file. If a file was chosen, it
triggers the upload and logs the status of the upload when it completes
successfully or with an error.
``` javascript
$w("#myUploadButton").fileType = "Image";        // visitor can choose an image only
$w('#myButton').onClick( () => {                 // visitor clicks a regular, non-upload button
if ($w("#myUploadButton").value.length > 0) {  // visitor chose a file
console.log("Uploading " + $w("#myUploadButton").value[0].name + "- Please wait.");
$w("#myUploadButton").startUpload()
.then( (uploadedFile) => {
console.log("Upload successful. File is available here:");
console.log(uploadedFile.url);
.catch( (uploadError) => {
console.log("File upload error: " + uploadError.errorCode);
console.log(uploadError.errorDescription);
else {    // site visitor clicked button but didn't choose a file
console.log("Please choose a file to upload.")
> **Note:** Because the `onChange()` event is fired before validation, note the following if you call the `startUpload()` function
inside the `onChange()` event handler: `startUpload()` returns promptly with an `UploadError` object if
the`fileSizeExceedsLimit` `validity` property or the `fileSizeExceedsLimit` `validity` property is true. If the validation
fails for one of these two reasons, the `startUpload()` does not attempt an upload.

docs.summary: Sets or gets the label on the upload button.
Sets or gets the type of the file that a site visitor can upload.
description: Setting the `fileType` property sets the type of the file that
a site visitor can upload. The value of `fileType` can be set to
`"Image"`, `"Document"`, `"Video"`, or `"Audio"`.
Getting the `fileType` property returns the current type of
file that a site visitor can upload.
The file types that can be uploaded are
listed [here](https://support.wix.com/en/article/supported-media-file-types-and-file-sizes).

docs.summary: Gets an object containing information about the upload button's styles.
description: The following styles can be used with upload buttons:
+ [`backgroundColor`]($w.Style.html#backgroundColor)
+ [`borderColor`]($w.Style.html#borderColor)
+ [`borderRadius`]($w.Style.html#borderRadius)
+ [`borderWidth`]($w.Style.html#borderWidth)
+ [`color`]($w.Style.html#color)
Getting or setting an upload button's styles, gets or sets the styles of the
upload button's regular state. It does not set the styles of the upload button's hover,
focus, error, or disabled states.

docs.summary: Indicates if a required file was selected, and if the file is valid for upload to the Media Manager.
description: The `valid` property indicates if the validation passed. `valid` is `false` if, for example:
+ A file was not selected, in cases where the file is required.
+ A file's type is not supported.
+ A file's size is not within the allowed limit.

+ There was a failed attempt to upload a file that passed input validation checks to the Media Manager with `startUpload()`. This could happen, for example, if the Internet connection is not stable. In this case, the `fileNotUploaded` `validity` property is also set to false.

examples.title: Get whether the file is valid for upload

docs.summary:
Gets a message indicating why the file is invalid or could not be uploaded. Contains
 empty string if the file is valid and successfully uploaded.
description: Set the value of the `validationMessage` property using the
[`reject()`](#reject) function of the [`onCustomValidation()`](#onCustomValidation)
event handler.
The message indicates why a file was not valid, or why a file could not be uploaded to the Media Manager. (This could happen, for example, if the Internet connection is not stable.)

docs.summary:
Gets a ValidityState object that contains
 detailed information about the validity states of the file to upload.
Returns a list of files that are pending upload.
description: Returns a list of `File` objects that a site visitor has selected to
upload after pressing the upload button.
See how `value` is used in a
[typical file upload scenario](#typical-scenario).

examples.title: Full file upload scenario
body: $w("#myUploadButton").fileType = "Image"; // site visitor can choose an image
if ($w("#myUploadButton").value.length > 0) {  // site visitor chose a file
console.log("Upload successful. File is available here:");
else {  // site visitor clicked button but didn't choose a file
console.log("Please choose a file to upload.")

extra.description:
This example uploads a file when the site visitor clicks on a button. First it sets 
 the type of the file a site visitor can choose. Then the example
 checks to see if the site visitor has chosen a file. If a file was chosen, it
 triggers the upload and logs the status of the upload when it completes
 successfully or with an error.

docs.summary: Clears the files that are pending upload.
description: The [`value`](#value) of the upload button contains a list of files that have been
selected to upload. The `reset()` function clears these files.

ret.doc:
Fulfilled - Resolves when the file upload is completed and returns an `UploadedFile` object.
Rejected - Rejects if the file upload fails and returns an `UploadError` object, which contains the error code and description.

docs.summary: Uploads the files that the site visitor has chosen.
description: The `startUpload()` function triggers the upload of the files in the
upload button's [value](#value) property.
See how `startUpload()` is used in a
[typical file upload scenario](#typical-scenario).

The upload button does not accept files larger than certain sizes, depending on the file type. Maximum allowed file sizes are listed [here](https://support.wix.com/en/article/supported-media-file-types-and-file-sizes).

`startUpload()` returns promptly (meaning, it does not attempt to contact the upload server) with `UploadError` when either the `validityState`'s `fileSizeExceedsLimit` or `fileTypeNotAllowed` property is `true`.

examples.title: Full file upload scenario
body: $w("#myUploadButton").fileType = "Image"; // site visitor can choose an image
if ($w("#myUploadButton").value.length > 0) {  // site visitor chose a file
console.log("Upload successful. File is available here:");
else {  // site visitor clicked button but didn't choose a file
console.log("Please choose a file to upload.")

extra.description:
This example uploads a file when the site visitor clicks on a button. First it sets 
 the type of the file a site visitor can choose. Then the example
 checks to see if the site visitor has chosen a file. If a file was chosen, it
 triggers the upload and logs the status of the upload when it completes
 successfully or with an error.

docs.summary: The object used by the [`value`](#value) property that represents files ready for upload.

members.name: name
members.doc: The file's name.

members.name: size
members.doc: The file's size in bytes.

docs.summary: The error message object returned when the `startUpload()`'s Promise is rejected.

members.name: errorCode
members.doc: The error's code.

members.name: errorDescription
members.doc: The error's description.

docs.summary: The object returned by the `startUpload()`'s Promise.

members.name: url
members.doc: The Wix URL of the successfully uploaded file.

members.name: mediaId
members.doc: The Wix media ID of the uploaded file.

members.name: title
members.doc: The title of the uploaded file.

members.name: width
members.doc: The width of an uploaded image or video file.

members.name: height
members.doc: The height of an uploaded image or video file.

members.name: duration
members.doc: The duration (in milliseconds) of an uploaded audio file.

docs.summary: Contains detailed information about the validity states of a file to upload.
description: States not related to file uploads can be ignored.

members.name: customError
members.doc: `true` if the file's custom validity message has been set to a non-empty string.

members.name: valid
members.doc: `true` if the file to upload meets all validations.

members.name: fileNotUploaded
members.doc: `true` if a file is required and a file has been selected but not uploaded.

members.name: fileSizeExceedsLimit
members.doc: `true` if a file has been selected but it is too large. Maximum allowed file sizes are listed [here](https://support.wix.com/en/article/supported-media-file-types-and-file-sizes).

members.name: fileTypeNotAllowed
members.doc: `true` if a file has been selected but the file's type is not supported. Supported file types are listed [here](https://support.wix.com/en/article/supported-media-file-types-and-file-sizes).

members.name: valueMissing
members.doc: `true` if a file is required but no file has been selected.

members.name: typeMismatch
members.doc: `true` if the element's value does not match its type when the type is email or url.

members.name: patternMismatch
members.doc: `true` if the element's value does not match its pattern validation.

members.name: tooLong
members.doc: `true` if the length of the element's value exceeds its [`maxlength`]($w.TextInputMixin.html#maxLength) property.

members.name: tooShort
members.doc: `true` if the length of the element's value is smaller than its minlength.

members.name: rangeUnderflow
members.doc: `true` if the element's value is less than the its [`min`]($w.TextInput.html#min) property.

members.name: rangeOverflow
members.doc: `true` if the element's value is more than the its [`max`]($w.TextInput.html#max) property.

members.name: badInput
members.doc: `true` if the element's value cannot be converted to a value.

FAQs.title: What types of files can site visitors upload with an upload button?
FAQs.markdown: You can set your upload button to upload images, documents, videos, or audio files using the [`fileType`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/$w.UploadButton.html#fileType) property. The file types of the images, documents, videos and audio files that can be uploaded are listed [here](https://support.wix.com/en/article/supported-media-file-types-and-file-sizes).

FAQs.title: How do I use an upload button on my site?
FAQs.markdown:
The typical file upload scenario is a two-part process. First your site visitor chooses the file to upload and then they trigger the actual upload. This usually requires at least two page elements, an upload button element and a regular button. 

The site visitor chooses which file to upload by clicking the upload button and selecting the file in a native file chooser dialog. (The site visitor can only choose from the specified file type.) Then the site visitor clicks the regular button to trigger some code that performs the upload. [Learn more](https://support.wix.com/en/article/how-to-use-the-upload-button-with-code).

FAQs.title: How do I get information about files that are pending an upload?
FAQs.markdown: Use [`value`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/$w.UploadButton.html#value) property to check the `name` and `size` of [`File`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/$w.UploadButton.html#File) objects waiting to be uploaded.
